findings.title: Compiler version not fixed
findings.description: The compiler version used to compile the contract is not fixed, which can lead to potential security vulnerabilities.

findings.title: Redundant fallback function
findings.description: The contract contains a redundant fallback function.

findings.title: Send instead of transfer
findings.description: Using 'send' instead of 'transfer' can lead to unintended behavior and potentially cause reentrancy vulnerabilities.

findings.title: Coding Style Issues in the Contract
findings.description: Code readability of a Smart Contract is largely influenced by the Coding Style issues and in some specific scenarios may lead to bugs in the future.

findings.title: Implicit visibility level
findings.description: Those functions that are never called throughout the contract should be marked as **external** visibility instead of **public** visibility.

findings.title: Ether Suffix should be used to symbolize the 10^18 zeros
findings.description: The finding suggests using Ether suffix to represent 10^18 zeros.

findings.title: Contract includes Hardcoded Addresses
findings.description: Keeping in mind the immutable nature of smart contracts, it is not considered a better practise to hardcode any address in the contract before deployment.

findings.title: Coding Style Issues in the Contract
